title: 106_hr412
content: The Trade Fairness Act of 1999 may be cited as the Trade Fairness Act. It provides relief from injury. The Trade Fairness Act of 1999, also known as the Trade Fairness Act, provides relief from injury by amending sections of the Trade Act of 1974 to remove the word "substantial" in relation to import competition adjustments and establish a causal link between imports and injury to the domestic industry. The Trade Fairness Act of 1999 amends the Trade Act of 1974 to establish a causal link between imports and injury to the domestic industry, removing the word "substantial" in relation to import competition adjustments. The Trade Fairness Act of 1999 establishes a Steel Import Permit and Monitoring Program. The Trade Fairness Act of 1999 establishes a steel import permit and monitoring program, requiring importers of products classified under chapter 72 or 73 of the Harmonized Tariff Schedule to obtain a permit from the Secretary of Commerce within 30 days of the Act's enactment. The permit application must include importer, supplier, and producer information. The import permit application must include details such as the country of origin, port of entry, expected entry date, goods description, quantity, CIF and FAS values, and purpose of entry. The import permit application must include details such as country of origin, port of entry, expected entry date, goods description, quantity, CIF and FAS values, and purpose of entry. A steel import permit is required for merchandise classified under chapter 72 or 73 of the Harmonized Tariff Schedule of the United States before entry into customs territory. The Secretary of Commerce will issue a steel import permit to applicants meeting the requirements. The Secretary of Commerce issues a steel import permit valid for 30 days. Weekly published information includes details from steel import permit applications like classification, country of origin, port of entry, quantity, value, and entry status. The Secretary of Commerce may charge fees for issuing permits under this section. Information on imports from single producer/exporter countries must be made publicly available. The Secretary of Commerce may prescribe regulations for the steel import permit program from foreign countries.
